page.title: 02Farming.
page.content: In Quarff, where so many people commute to full time employment, crofting has become a spare time occupation. A croft is a small area of arable land used for mixed farming. In addition, a crofter also has a share in the "scattald." Most crofters rent their crofts, and, under the Crofting Acts, have security of tenure and therefore cannot be evicted. A croft is always busy and there is always something to do. For example, spring is the lambing time and peats have to be cut for winter fuel. In early summer the rye grass is cut and the peats are taken home. In mid summer the sheep have to be clipped and the wool is sold. In late summer the hay is baled or 'coled' and taken home for winter feeding. In autumn the lambs are taken to the marts to be sold.
